bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, January 27, 1938

div1.p: Hench informs Moran of his continued plans to publish Moran's and Kissinger's memoirs. He offers medical advice and invites Moran to visit the Mayo Clinic.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, January 27, 1938
div1.opener:
January 27, 1938
Mr. John J. Moran
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S.A.
Avenida Menocal No. 102-A
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
You have a right to chide me for not being a prompt correspondent,
but my associate has been away, leaving an extra burden of work on me.

First of all, let me thank you very kindly indeed for your valued
publications concerning the yellow fever experiments. I am returning by separate
post, The Popular Science Monthy article and the Roll of Honor. I was able to
get copies of these two. So far I have not been able to get a copy of the
Military Surgeon, and I am asking to keep this some weeks longer.

I shall take the liberty some time of writing Mr. J. H. Andrus and
Mr. James L. Hanberry. I had planned to collaborate with you and Mr. Kissinger
and write up your experiences under your names some time this year, of course
submitting the manuscripts long ahead of time for your entire perusal, correction
and approval, but I have been so busy that I have been unable to do much on it
yet. Now that you and Mr. Kissinger both tell me that the published stories
are not entirely correct, I want to take plenty of time to do this so that we
may have an entirely correct story, omitting such parts that you and Mr. Kissinger
think should not be published. My original plan is unchanged--to have each of
you write your own story, to be published separately in a medical historical
journal under your own names, with the right of republication in non-medical
journals to be in your hands, and to be published as you see fit.

Now as to the personal questions which you ask about: I spoke to
Dr. Crenshaw about you some time ago and showed him your letter. He is very much
interested to know where you are. At first he was a little hazy on your
identity, since he remembers three Morans. He was at the University of Virginia,
academic, 1901-02, medical, 1902-06. He is one of our most valued members of
the staff here. He says that he is going to write you shortly. You can reach
him simply by addressing him at the Mayo Clinic.

In regard to your own difficulties: I wish indeed that I could be
of some assistance to you by mail. We have a special department here for the
care and treatment of patients with stomach and duodenal diseases, and I dis-
cussed your letter with one of my colleagues in that department. You will
appreciate that there are so many factors involved in the treatment of duodenal
ulcer that it is impossible for me to give you any advice by mail, although
I should like to be of any possible service to you. We have many patients
with your condition who come here, and other things being all right, our

surgeons do not hesitate to operate upon a man of sixty-two whose general
condition is satisfactory, and often a great deal can be accomplished.
Other than surgery, you know the medical management of such conditions
usually involves the avoidance of excesses of tobacco and alcohol, a fairly
strict diet, and the use of certain alkaline powders and feedings between
meals. Should you see fit to come to the Clinic for a thorough examination
I shall be delighted to expedite your examination, and would personally see
to it that the expense of the whole thing be kept down to the absolute
minimum. I personally wish that I could promise you that your examinations
would be gratis, but this is not within my province. Nevertheless, I can
assure you that any general expense involved in the trip here would be
entirely within your means and to your entire satisfaction.

Now regarding Mr. Andrus: I hesitate to inject myself into an
argument between two groups of physicians, with Mr. Andrus' son on the one
side and the physicians of the Walter Reed Hospital on the other. Nevertheless,
I should like to be of service in any way possible and it so happens that I
am in charge of the work on arthritis here. If, as Mr. Andrus' son feels,
he has arthritis, I should be glad to cooperate with Dr. Andrus in any way
possible. May I suggest that it might be more diplomatic if you would write
to Mr. Andrus and suggest that his son write to me. Everything would then be
in order and I should be glad to help in every way possible. If it were
necessary or if it seemed expedient for him to be brought here, I should be
glad to do all I could. There is not much to be done for syringomyelia,
although there is an operation which is indicated in certain special cases.

If you do plan to come here, please let me know well ahead of time
so that I can get everything set for you. I have to go to two medical con-
ferences in England and will be away from the fourteenth of March to the nine-
teenth of May. If you have any intentions of coming here perhaps it would be
better to come either before or after these dates.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
